div1.p: Sternberg provides his impressions of Reed and his work relative to Kelly's plans to write a biography of Reed.

div1.head: Letter from George Miller Sternberg to Howard A. Kelly, December 12, 1902
div1.opener:
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
The Washington Post-Graduate Medical School.
Board of Directors.
GENERAL GEORGE M. STERNBERG, U. S. A., PRESIDENT,
(ADDRESS, 2144 CALIFORNIA AVENUE.)
J. FORD THOMPSON, VICE-PRESIDENT,
GEORGE M. KOBER, SECRETARY AND TREASURER,
WALTER WYMAN,
SURGEON GENERAL PUBLIC HEALTH
AND MARINE HOSPITAL SERVICE,
P. M. MIXEY
SURGEON GENERAL U. S. NAVY,
R. M. O'REILLY,
SURGEON GENERAL U. S. ARMY,
A. D. RICHARDSON,
SUPT. GOVERNMENT HOSPITAL FOR
THE INSANE.
SAMUEL S. ADAMS, M. D.
EDWARD A. BALLOCH, M. D.
SWAN M. BURNETT, M. D.
H. L. E. JOHNSON, M. D.
JOSEPH TABER JOHNSON, M. D.
E. A. DE SCHWEINITZ, M. D.
STERLING RUFFIN, M. D.
WM. C. WOODWARD, M. D.
Washington, D. C. Dec. 12th 1902
Dear Dr. Kelly:
div1.p:
I am glad to know that
you will write a memorial of Major
Walter Reed, whose death is so sincerly
regretted by all who knew him.

During my nine years service as
Surgeon General of the army I en-
trusted him with various important
duties & he never failed to perform
them to my entire satisfaction. He
was selected by me as President of
the board organized to investigate
the causes of the prevalence of typhoid
fever in our Camps during the
Spanish-American war & also as
President of a board forthe
study of yellow fever. The valuable
results accomplished by both of these
boards are now matters of history.
Dr. Reed had excellent judgement in
devising & carrying out plans for
research work & had learned to
rely upon the results of scientific
experiments rather than upon a
priors' reasoning for the settlement
of the etiological problems which he
was called upon to investigate. I had
a He was extremely conservative in
drawing conclusions from his
experimental work, but very firm
in supporting his conclusions when
they had a reliable experimental
basis. His death has deprived the
Medical Corps of the Army of one of
its brightest armaments & science
of one of its most devoted &
successful notaries.

closer.seg: P.S. I mailed the letter to Mrs. Reed.
